item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Enthusiastic fans are flocking to collect merchandise and souvenirs from the Beijing Winter Olympics. In a 20 square meter (215 sq ft) room deep in an alleyway in the Chinese capital, 35-year-old Zhang Wenquan keeps around 5,000 Olympic souvenirs - mascots, flags, torches and pins. He's collected the assorted items from around the world - Beijing, Sochi, Munich, Pyeongchang - since the last Beijing Games in 2008. Zhang said he's felt a special connection with the Olympics ever since he worked as a volunteer in 2008, delivering score cards. He claims to have invested over 500,000 RMB (78,600 US dollars) in his hobby. I check online about every hour and see if there is new Olympic souvenir released, said Zhang. My life has been filled with the Olympics. Though eager to be part of the Winter Games scheduled to open Friday, Zhang couldn't be a volunteer or buy a ticket for the opening ceremony, due to strict coronavirus measures. I have been trying so hard to watch it at the scene, but because of the epidemic, there may be no chance, he said.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) The dissident Chinese artist behind the giant lattice-style Bird's Nest venue in Beijing that was hosting Friday's opening ceremonies of the Winter Games had tough words for China's government and others that kowtow to it. Ai Weiwei mocked what he called the Chinese government's excessive and ineffectual lockdown measures to fight COVID-19, and its poor human rights record – saying hopes that it might have improved since Beijing hosted the 2008 Summer Games have gone unfulfilled. I think it's really, really unbelievable after 14 years of this -- this game, same game -- we turn to the same country, a country (that has) not developed an inch towards better human rights and the better freedom of speech conditions, but rather become very arrogant, he told the Associated Press in an interview by video conference. The Chinese dissident widely regarded as one of the world’s greatest living artists has repeatedly described the 2008 Olympics as a “fake smile” that his native country presented to the world. Ai Weiwei also took aim at the International Olympic Committee, saying the Winter Games means big business for them. He faulted the IOC, saying it never protected human rights and has shown itself to always defend … whatever China is doing – and which is a pity. He chuckled derisively when told about a tweet from World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, who tweeted a photo of himself in a red-and-white Beijing 2022 winter track suit and matching wool cap as he carried the Olympic flame during the torch relay in China. Under Tedros, the U.N. health agency came in for severe criticism from then-U.S. President Donald Trump's administration in 2020 for its alleged missteps and excessive deference to and praise for China when the COVID-19 pandemic first appeared in the city of Wuhan and its surrounding some two years ago. He should get a gold medal from China because he never asked the right question. Ai Weiwei quipped. Where is his conscience, this guy? You know, all those people who are supposed to defend the human health and give the right information, but never ask the right question and always on the side of the propaganda, he said. They're so ridiculous, Ai Weiwei added. The artist didn't give a pass to other countries either – both those like Russia, which were represented at the highest official levels, and some Western countries who boycotted the Games or decided to stay away for reasons like COVID-19 concerns, faulting them for a double-standard. They very, like, softly say, 'we are not officially attending'. For me, that is like a joke, AI Weiwei said. So the West -- the problem is, cannot find a better strategy -- but to use that as like a smoke gun to say, 'OK, we're defending those principles.' But in the reality, they are not: They are business as normal, he added.

item.title: Exiled artist Ai Weiwei reflects on Beijing Olympics

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) LEAD IN: Forced to leave their homeland after the Taliban seized power, two young Afghan women have opened a restaurant in the Albanian coast city of Shengjin. By serving Afghan dishes to the around 1,000 refugees now staying in the coastal town, the two women hope to provide a welcome taste of home.
STORY-LINE: Visiting a local supermarket in the Albanian coastal town of Shengjin, 22-year-old Walwala Jalalzay and 19-year-old Maryam Aslami are searching for ingredients. The two young Afghan refugees have opened a restaurant called Kabul-Shengjin. The idea is to bring the taste of home to the around 1,000 Afghan refugees now staying in the city. They use the few Albanian words they've managed to learn during their three-month stay to order the goods they desire. At first, when we were coming here, we were using some body language to describe what do we want, says Jalalzay. Slowly, we are learning names, and we are learning things that we want, and we know the places that where is the location of something, where is the position of something that we can use. Back at the restaurant, to the sound of music from their motherland, they open the eatery every day. Maryam's two sisters also help make food and serve the customers. When we came here, obviously, we missed our country, we missed our people, we missed the environment, we missed our parents back behind, but we cannot go back to our country, and maybe they cannot come in here. So, the only thing now that we can do is to bring the taste of the foods in here, says Jalalzay. We decided to open the restaurant to bring the taste of home in here. The restaurant has become an attraction for locals hoping to sample Afghan food. We found the dishes very interesting. It is the first time we tried (Afghan food), says local Sonila Islamaj. Albania has sheltered thousands of Afghan evacuees in hotels or tourist resorts. The Balkan country was one of the first to offer to host up to 4,000 Afghan refugees. But Jalalzay doesn't intend to stay here. She's waiting on clearance to travel to the United States and join her brothers who are both living in Virginia. She doesn't know how long she'll stay in Shengjin but knowing the situation in her home country - especially when it comes to women's rights - she feels blessed for have found her way to Albania. Since their return to power, the Taliban have imposed widespread restrictions, many of them directed at women. Disappointed with what's happening back in her home country, Jalalzay still hopes things will get better. We hope they (Taliban) stand up on their promises that they have given, she says. At the first, they said they will let girls and ladies to have their rights, to be educated, to go out. So, now we are seeing they are doing the opposite of what they say. So, I just hope the situation gets better soon. The Taliban's sweep to power in Afghanistan in August drove billions of dollars in international assistance out of the country and sent an already dirt-poor nation, ravaged by war, drought and floods, spiraling toward a humanitarian catastrophe. It's estimated that roughly 90 percent of Afghanistan's 38 million people are dependent on aid and the U.N. says nearly 3 million are displaced in their own country, driven from their homes by drought, war and famine.

item.title: Afghan restaurant gives refugees welcome taste of home

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Families played games and danced at a government-run sports-themed plaza in Beijing on Friday in anticipation of the opening of the 2022 Winter Olympics. Even if the Olympics are being held with strict COVID-19 prevention measures, with spectators being asked to clap instead of cheer, there was still a festive air in the capital city. At the Winter Olympics Culture Plaza in Beijing, neighborhood dance troupes performed as families gathered to join in the excitement. I hope that that our athletes do well, and together show the world our future, said Liu Jingyun, who was part of a group of dancers. Her team of dancers had already started preparing to welcome the Games four years ago by decorating the flat taiping drums they performed with snowflakes. Another group swirled through the plaza on rollerblades, wearing matching red and white outfits and helmets. Because Beijing is a dual-Olympic city, we are incomparably proud and excited that Beijing is hosting the Winter Olympics, said rollerblader Qiang Junxian. Much of the event was staffed by volunteers like Zhang Xinrui, a college senior. This Winter Olympics, it's like an international festival, and as a volunteer, it's a hugely important thing for me as a college student, and even in my life, Zhang said. The Chinese government, in hosting the Winter Olympics, has actively promoted winter sports, and that has successfully spread to some of its population.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) Argentina has reached an agreement with the International Monetary Fund to refinance more than $40 billion in debt, President Alberto Fernández said Friday. Speaking at a news conference after the announcement Argentina's Economic Minister laid out some of the details of the agreement. Argentina was able to reach a policy agreement with the International Monetary Fund without there being adjustment policies, stated Martin Guzman. The exchange rate policy is going to continue along the lines in which it has been carried out and we set an objective of accumulation of international reserves, which is very important to favor resilience on the external front, he said. Since 2020, Argentina has been in an arduous negotiation with the IMF to refinance the debt contracted in 2018 during the government of conservative Mauricio Macri in the midst of a currency crisis. Argentina had spent three years trying to renegotiate repayment terms with the IMF and considered a deal vital to stabilizing an economy whose lengthy crisis has been hit as well by the pandemic.

(28 Jan 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4363518, 4363536
Dominique Luzuriaga, the wife of slain NYPD police officer Jason Rivera, spoke at her husband's funeral on Friday. She lashed out at new Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg, a Democrat who has instructed prosecutors not to pursue certain cases, including some allegations of resisting arrest. Rivera and Officer Wilbert Mora were fatally wounded a week ago when a gunman ambushed them in an apartment as they responded to a family dispute. Bragg, who had no involvement with the officers' killer, responded in a statement that he was grieving and praying for the slain officers and will vigorously prosecute cases of violence against police.

(28 Jan 2022) RESTRICTION SUMMARY: STORYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS San Pablo - 27 de enero de 2022 La población sin hogar en la ciudad de San Pablo aumentó un 31 por ciento durante la pandemia de COVID-19, según datos de un nuevo censo. Las autoridades registraron casi 32.000 personas viviendo en la calle. Cifra más elevada que la del resto de las ciudades del país. Luiz Carlos da Silva fue uno de los que se quedó sin hogar durante la pandemia. Desde septiembre del año pasado, duerme en una carpa improvisada en la acera con su esposa, embarazada de tres meses. SOUNDBITE (Portugués) - Luiz Carlos da Silva, persona sin hogar: Hasta el año pasado yo tenía una buena vida. Tenía mi casa, mis bienes, tenía todo, y mira dónde estoy ahora, dijo da Silva. Otra familia sin un techo es la de Sheila Carvalho de Souza. Ella y sus cuatro hijos reciben donaciones de ropa y alimento de un residente local. SOUNDBITE (Portugués) - Sheila Carvalho de Souza, persona sin hogar: Hoy voy a comer carne porque recibí esta comida y hay mucha comida aquí, dijo de Souza, quien recoge artículos reciclables en las calles. El censo se iba a realizar en 2023, pero el gobierno local lo adelantó debido a la escalada de pobreza agravada por la pandemia y la necesidad de generar proyectos para esta población. Según el Instituto Brasileño de Geografía y Estadística, había 13,5 millones de personas desempleadas en el país en el tercer trimestre de 2021. Yesica Brumec, Associated Press =========================================================== Clients are reminded: (i) to check the terms of their licence agreements for use of content outside news programming and that further advice and assistance can be obtained from the AP Archive on: Tel +44 (0) 20 7482 7482 Email: info@aparchive.com (ii) they should check with the applicable collecting society in their Territory regarding the clearance of any sound recording or performance included within the AP Television News service (iii) they have editorial responsibility for the use of all and any content included within the AP Television News service and for libel, privacy, compliance and third party rights applicable to their Territory.

(4 Feb 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4364474
Enthusiastic fans are flocking to collect merchandise and souvenirs from the Beijing Winter Olympics. In a 20 square meter (215 sq ft) room deep in an alleyway in the Chinese capital, 35-year-old Zhang Wenquan keeps around 5,000 Olympic souvenirs - mascots, flags, torches and pins. He's collected the assorted items from around the world - Beijing, Sochi, Munich, Pyeongchang - since the last Beijing Games in 2008. Zhang said he's felt a special connection with the Olympics ever since he worked as a volunteer in 2008, delivering score cards. He claims to have invested over 500,000 RMB (78,600 US dollars) in his hobby. Sometimes I wake up for auctions at 2 or 3 in the morning, said Zhang. My life has been filled with the Olympics. Though eager to be part of the Winter Games scheduled to open Friday, Zhang couldn't be a volunteer or buy a ticket for the opening ceremony, due to strict coronavirus measures. Meanwhile, hundreds of Beijing residents queued in front of a Beijing Olympics souvenir store for a chance to purchase memorabilia.

item.description:
(29 Jan 2022) LEAD IN: On the steep and narrow streets of an ancient city in Kosovo, bins are still collected by horse. Where modern vehicles can't go, a bin collector and his horse continue to assure a public service.
STORY-LINE: For the last four decades, the city of Prizren in Kosovo has had an unusual bin collecting duo: Nexhmedin Berisha, 66, and his horse. Five days a week, they go up and down the narrow cobbled streets of the old neighbourhood of Nenkala (Under castle), something which has turned them into local heroes. No vehicles can climb the steep streets of this part of the city, located 85 kilometres (50 miles) southwest of the capital Pristina. Prizren, Kosovo's second most populous city, is on the banks of a river and features a fortress overlooking the city. The site has been used since the Bronze Age according to archaeological excavations. Berisha collects bin bags from each house in Nenkala, a neighbourhood often nicknamed quarter of the windows since houses were built so close to each other. With the pandemic there have been many difficulties for people but this man has always come to our houses to collect waste. He is a successful, glorious man for the residents of this neighbourhood. It is very difficult for him, with the slopes but he still goes to take the waste, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. There have been many people infected with the virus but he goes. We are very pleased, says Pash Moneka, a resident in Prizren's Nenkala quarter. Local authorities are pleased with his work, which helps preserve the city's ancient site. I've been doing this job for 44 years. Only the horse can pass through these streets. With my horse I collect the waste and have always continued to work, respecting the job, says Berisha, while holding his horse. I have never stopped, regardless of the snow or the rain. I have never stopped working. Where the trucks can't go uphill I go with the horse. I have never had any obstacle from people. I am always ready, in death funerals or weddings, always trying to leave them (the people) satisfied. I have never had problems with them, now for 44 years. And that's the most important thing to Berisha: continuity. The reason why we are using a horse in these streets is because the trucks cannot go to this old part of Prizren. The paths are very narrow and only the horse may pass through them and that protects old Prizren, traditions of the old Prizren. We have always applied this form of service. Even during the pandemic, we have not stopped. We have done such a service five days per week, says Flamur Nomlexhiu from the waste management company of Eko Region. Collecting the waste is not the only service which has turned Berisha into a local hero. His horse almost never climbs back empty - it brings food and other goods Berisha buys at the city for the retired people up in his quarter. Berisha is paid 210 Euros ($238) per month, just enough money to support himself.
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork Twitter: https://twitter.com/AP_Archive Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/APArchives ​​ Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/APNews/

item.description:
(29 Jan 2022) PIERRE CARDIN COLLECTION PAYS TRIBUTE TO LATE DESIGNER WITH SPACE AGE CONCEPT It was fitting that Friday (28 JANUARY 2022) evening's homage to Pierre Cardin—a fashion show in his honor—took place at the Le Bourget Air and Space Museum, north of Paris. The iconic French designer is famous for his space age fashions going back to the 1960s. He passed away in December 2020, at age 98, but he was still designing up until the end. The collection, Cosmocorps 3022, was shown outside, at the foot of an Ariane 5 European space launch vehicle. It was also livestreamed to audiences in Tirana, Moscow, Dallas, and Mexico, many of them young students in the fashion industry. The show started with archival footage of the late designer and his creations on two giant screens. This was followed by 30 of the last looks designed by Cardin, realized in the Paris atelier. There were the bold pop colors, the mid-thigh trapeze dresses in stretchy fabrics, the unisex jumpsuits worthy of Star Trek, as well as exaggerated shoulders, cutouts and circular details, skinny futuristic sunglasses, and shiny black ankle boots. Part two represented the house's future, under the reins of Cardin's nephew, Rodrigo Basilicati-Cardin, the current CEO and artistic director. Working with three other designers from the studio, he created a collection for women and men that was still recognizably Cardin: two-tone jersey dresses in daring shades, such as red with magenta; stiff geometric shoulders and collars, colorful long capes for men. One dress featured a pair of brilliant pink hoops, like hula hoops. Others featured stiff disc-like shapes around the hips or torso. Metallic long evening gowns reflected the light. At the end, a woman dressed in white came out and danced like a whirling dervish, her skirt flaring as she moved. After the show, Basilicati-Cardin said the company has had the most loyal staff, which contributed to its success and continuity. In the house I have people who have been working for 60 years…they lived all their life with us. Which is something special, it is not normal. I have to maintain that.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) The town of Chebaa is used to snow in January but a recent storm, which has blanketed most of Lebanon, has left the town with snowfall the town hasn't been seen in a decade. Snow trucks struggle to keep up with the amount of snow, leading many mountainous roads in Lebanon closed due to the weather. The roads are opening but that's not helping because the weather as you can see, a storm one right after the other. So the roads are staying closed so it has been hard to move around, said Mohammad Daher, a Chebaa resident. A winter storm has been battering the eastern Mediterranean, bringing heavy rains and wind to the Middle East this past week. Temperatures reached below 0 Celsius in some parts of the Middle East. Lebanon, a country of 6 million people, is home to 1.5 million Syrian refugees and as Lebanon grapples with an unprecedented economic crisis, poverty has deepened the Lebanese people. Sky-rocketing fuel prices coupled with a currency collapse has meant many essential commodities, including fuel needed for heaters, are now out of reach for the average citizen. For Dalal Moussa, the cold weather has isolated her in her home. A person can't even go outside to go get some fruits even. We can even check on each other. Nothing. There is no diesel. If someone has a little bit of diesel, he's using it lightly so that we can last the winter, she said. She turns off her heater at night to save on diesel and only stays warm in the coldest hours of the day with just blankets. And with no electricity, an electric heater is not a choice for many in Lebanon.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) Portugal on Friday ended two weeks of political campaigning for national elections, coming amidst an omicron surge in the country. On Friday leader of the Social Democrats, the main opposition party, Rui Rio gathered hundreds of supporters in downtown Lisbon as a show of confidence ahead of Sunday's vote. In recent days, polls have brought the two running candidates closer, with speculation that either Rio and current Prime Minister and Socialist leader Antonio Costa could win. The country's facing a snap election for a new parliament and government follows a political crisis caused when the minority government formed by the Socialists in 2019 collapsed last November, halfway through its four-year term, when parliament rejected its 2022 state budget. The spending plan is key. Portugal, a country of 10.3 million people, is poised to begin deploying some 45 billion euros ($50.8 billion) in help from the EU to help fire up the economy after the COVID-19 pandemic. The new funds are seen as a chance for Portugal to make up lost economic ground. But the snap election, intended to clarify the country's direction, could backfire and leave Portugal back where it started two months ago - with a vulnerable minority government. An apparent surge in support for smaller parties means the two main parties will likely have to cut a deal with one or more of them, with an extended period of political negotiation expected. The country's two main parties, the center-left Socialists and the center-right Social Democrats, have alternated in power for decades, but Portugal's problems have continued.
Those two parties have for decades collected around 70% of the vote, alternating in government, and opinion polls suggest a close race between them this time.
Portugal's economy has been falling behind the rest of the EU since 2000, when its real annual GDP per capita was 16,230 euros ($18,300) compared with an EU average of 22,460 ($25,330). By 2020, Portugal had edged higher to 17,070 euros ($19,250) while the bloc's average surged to 26,380 euros ($29,750).
Sunday's ballot is taking place amid a surge in cases blamed on the highly infectious omicron coronavirus variant, with hundreds of thousands of infected people confined at home. To reconcile the constitutional right to vote and the duty to care for public health, authorities are allowing infected people to go to polling stations, with a recommendation they go in a less busy evening time slot.

(28 Jan 2022) RESTRICTION SUMMARY: STORYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS Donetsk, Ucrania - 27 de enero de 2022 A medida que crece la tensión en la frontera entre Ucrania y Rusia, los residentes de un pueblo en las afueras de Donetsk esperan la paz. Spartak, que todavía alberga a unas 80 familias, está cerca del frente del lado rebelde. La mayoría de sus habitantes son personas mayores que rara vez salen a la calle, por temor a la amenaza de bombardeos. SOUNDBITE (Ruso) - Valentina Pleshkovam, residente: Solo esperamos que Rusia nos tome de una vez, porque esto tiene que detenerse en algún momento, dijo esta residente. La tensión se ha disparado en las últimas semanas. Estados Unidos y sus aliados de la OTAN temen un ataque de Moscú al ex estado soviético, por las tropas rusas desplegadas cerca de la frontera. Rusia ha negado planes de invasión. SOUNDBITE (Ruso) - Irina (no dio apellido), residente: Lo que está pasando ahora es no una guerra, es un fratricidio. Nosotros y Ucrania somos lo mismo, hemos sido lo mismo, dijo esta residente. Mientras Moscú y Occidente evalúan sus próximos pasos, la OTAN dijo que estaba reforzando su disuasión en la región del Mar Báltico, y Estados Unidos ordenó a 8.500 soldados en alerta máxima. Rusia ha lanzado una serie de ejercicios militares en el suroeste de su país, en Kaliningrado, en el Mar Báltico y en el Mar Negro y el Ártico. Sus tropas también se dirigieron a Bielorrusia, lo que aumentó los temores de Occidente de que Moscú pudiera organizar un ataque contra Ucrania desde el norte. item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Thousands of journalists from around the world were working under strict COVID-19 restrictions Friday at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. The opening ceremony is due to begin on Friday evening local time. Confined to a 'closed-loop' to prevent an outbreak of infections, journalists can only visit a limited number of sites and are not allowed to move freely through the Chinese capital. We feel here like we are in jail, said Viki Ivanovic, a senior reporter from Croatia's national broadcaster HRT. We can't go out of the hotel, police is outside, a big fence is there. I can't feel the Olympic spirit. But other journalists said the restrictions were an important way to keep infection at bay, especially as the omicron variant continues to rage around the world. Organizers said nine more athletes and officials tested positive for COVID-19 on Thursday, raising the total to 111 since Jan. 23. Seven cases were detected at the airport, and two came from daily PCR testing that all people inside the Olympic bubbles must undergo. Organizers said 12 more positive cases were detected among stakeholders — mostly workers at the Games, including the press. Seven of those were at the airport and five were in daily tests. The overall total of positive cases is 308 through Thursday. Almost 12,000 people have arrived in Beijing from outside China.

(28 Jan 2022) RESTRICTION SUMMARY: PART MUST CREDIT NOAA, DO NOT OBSCURE PERMIT NUMBER NOAA – MUST CREDIT; DO NOT OBSCURE PERMIT NUMBER Off Maui, Hawaii – 26 January 2022 ++QUALITY AS INCOMING++ 1. Rescue crew attaches line to gear entangling whale 2. Rescue crew grapples gear entangling whale ++4X3 VIDEO AS INCOMING++ 3. Various, rescue crew pulls up behind whale 4. Rescue crew frees whale from entangled gear ++MUTE++ STORYLINE: Federal officials say a yearling humpback whale off Hawaii has been freed from a life-threatening entanglement in mooring gear. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said a rescue team cut off about 140 feet (43 meters) of line and a plastic trawling buoy when they freed the whale off Maui on Wednesday. The whale's tail and fins were wrapped in small-gauge line with the plastic buoy floating behind, the agency said in a statement. Officials said the whale was in good condition but that the line wrapped around its tail had begun to cut into the animal's flesh. The gear was of considerable weight, the agency said. The gear will be analyzed to determine its exact source. The animal's behavior was very evasive, and while it stayed near the surface, it maintained unusually rapid speeds, at times in excess of six knots, the agency said in a statement Thursday. Trained responders cut the gear off with a blade attached to a pole after getting close on an inflatable boat. It is a federal crime to approach a humpback whale and the team was working under under federal permit. Another humpback whale was spotted of Hawaii earlier this month, also entangled in debris. =========================================================== Clients are reminded: (i) to check the terms of their licence agreements for use of content outside news programming and that further advice and assistance can be obtained from the AP Archive on: Tel +44 (0) 20 7482 7482 Email: info@aparchive.com (ii) they should check with the applicable collecting society in their Territory regarding the clearance of any sound recording or performance included within the AP Television News service (iii) they have editorial responsibility for the use of all and any content included within the AP Television News service and for libel, privacy, compliance and third party rights applicable to their Territory.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Forces of Yemen's internationally-recognized government have reclaimed large swathes of territory in a southern province from Iran-backed Houthi rebels, government officials said. The Yemeni Armed Forces Media Centre stated on its official page on Twitter that the army forces, backed by the popular resistance, have liberated several sites from the Houthi militia control in the Mas front, northwest of Marib. The push in the southern province of Shabwa comes amid heavy airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition battling the Houthis elsewhere in Yemen, including the capital, Sanaa. The rebels have also stepped up their cross-border attacks, using ballistic missiles and explosive-laden drones to target Saudi Arabia. Yemen's civil war began in 2014 when the Houthis took Sanaa and much of the northern part of the country, forcing the government to flee to the south, then to Saudi Arabia. The conflict has since become a regional proxy war that has killed tens of thousands of civilians and fighters. Government troops, aided by fighters from the Giants Brigades militia, swept through Shabwa earlier this month, retaking most of the Usaylan district from the Houthis.

item.description:
(29 Jan 2022) LEAD IN: The traditional Chinese New Year celebrations in London have been scaled down once again because of the pandemic, but smaller events will go ahead. The London Eye will light up in red and gold to welcome in the Year of the Tiger and restaurants will be open. But organisers are asking people not to come en mass to China Town.
STORY-LINE: New lanterns for the Chinese New Year. London's Chinatown is getting ready for it biggest event, but this year, festivities are being scaled down due to the pandemic. Usually, London's celebration of the Chinese New Year is the biggest outside of Asia. Basically, as you know, every year we have a parade, we have lots of performances in Trafalgar Square, half a million visitors come to London (pre-pandemic) and we're having Charing Cross Road and also Chinatown is all pedestrians spaces. And then we have five stages performing all different cultural activities and lots of people come over and we celebrate Chinese New Year together. But unfortunately, this year we have to scale down so much, says Lawrence Lee, Spokesperson for the London Chinatown Chinese Association. For now, the London Chinatown Chinese Association, which organises the event, is busy putting up new lanterns. So we are luckily having sponsorship from the local businesses and also some banks. So a lot of lanterns, they will bear their names on it. And so it's just to symbolise their sponsorship and their charitable means. And also this year, it's been all designed and made in China. And then we shipped them over, says Lee. But the event is being planned to cater to a more local audience spread across the two weeks of the Spring Festival. For the organisers, it's a difficult balance to strike: attract visitors, but not too many. We have to protect the general public. We don't stop to encourage people to come in masses, you know, to celebrate together, and they will be able to see our programmes on TV. And I do hope that people don't all rush into Chinatown because they can easily come and celebrate in the future. And because the Chinese New Year lasts for two weeks. So they can always come along and have some nice food and celebrate with us, says Lee. A market will be held from 5 p.m. until 10 p.m. in Chinatown on Monday (31 January). The London Eye will also light up in red and gold colours. Laura Citron, CEO of London and Partners says people still can to come to London to enjoy the Chinese restaurants and shops over the New Year celebrations. We're really excited about Chinese New Year in London this year. We won't be having the big festivities on Trafalgar Square that we've had in previous years for obvious reasons. But we're having a fantastic night market here in Chinatown behind me and our Chinese community is going to be celebrating and all of our favourite Chinese restaurants and shops will be open. So I think we're all really looking forward as Londoners to coming out celebrating Chinese New Year. Most people are expected to mark the occasion in a more intimate and private setting, most likely at home. It's the case of Laiyuen Choi, a Londoner from China. I'm going to have a dinner with my friends in a house. So we're probably going to have a hodgepodge, obviously. And we're going to play some games or something like that, says Choi. Restaurants and supermarkets are stocking up to face the peak of demand early next week, but not anywhere near the same quantities they used to order pre-pandemic.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Sri Lanka celebrated its 74th Independence Day from the UK with a state ceremony presided over by President Gotabaya Rajapaksa. This year's Independence Day ceremony is being held in keeping with the health guidelines due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic situation. The event takes place with the participation of 6,500 personnel from the armed forces and police. The celebrations come amid one of the worst economic hardships in the country's history with imports for consumption and industries curtailed because of an acute foreign reserve shortage and high debt repayment obligations. Rajapaksa in his speech called upon the people to have a positive attitude amid the crises. The world has been changed and will be changed by those people with positive ideas, who dream of a future with optimism and strive to make it a reality. We see this throughout the history. Social progress in all developed nations has been possible due to the positive thoughts of their leaders and the people, he said. Difficult times do not last forever. People of great resolve are needed to face difficult times. Anyone who demoralizes another is not doing any good to the society at this moment. Therefore, all of us have an enormous responsibility to build a positive attitude in the country to face these crises successfully, Rajapaksa said.

item.title: Sri Lanka marks 74th anniversary of independence

item.description:
(29 Jan 2022) A commemorative march for cadets who died fighting against the invading Russian Red Army in 1918 took place in the Ukrainian capital Kyiv on Saturday. On January 29, Ukraine honours 'Kruty Heroes' who died defending Kyiv, delaying the advance of the Red Army. For many, honouring the bravery of fallen victims is especially important now, as fears rise that Russia is preparing to invade the Ukraine. The Kremlin denies it is planning an invasion. I understand that Ukraine is extremely important for me just as it was for them. This is what they fought for and gave their lives for this, said Anastasia Kovalskaya. Civilians and military members took part in the march and laid flowers at the graves of young soldiers. This is important because it was the first manifestation of the heroism of the Ukrainian patriotic forces in the fight against our primordial enemy - the Moscow invaders, said Kyiv resident Georgy Lukenchuk.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4364422
Some residents of Ukraine's second-largest city, Kharkiv, have been preparing to abandon their civilian lives and fight back if Russian forces invade. The situation in Kharkiv, just 40 kilometers (25 miles) from the border where tens of thousands of Russian troops have massed, feels particularly perilous. Last week, volunteers for Ukraine's Territorial Defense Forces were attending training sessions to get to grips with weapons and acquire basic defense skills. The Ukrainian Army chaplain was on hand to give the group a heartfelt blessing. Kharkiv is a city of fractures: between Ukrainian speakers and those who stick with the Russian language that dominated until recently; and between those who enthusiastically volunteer to resist a Russian offensive and those who just want to live their lives. Local pensioner Ivan Vasilyevich said he wanted to see unity between Russia, Belarus and Ukraine. If there were unity between Russia, Belarus and Ukraine, that would be a strong united state that Europe could not defeat, he said. There are growing calls in Washington for the United States to support a potential Ukrainian insurgency.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Crowds of people gathered in central Beijing Friday to watch fireworks being set off over the Bird's Nest stadium during the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics. Many said they were filled with pride and filmed the fireworks with their phones. I am very excited because it is a once-in-a-generation opportunity for Beijing to host the Winter Olympic Games, said Xu Pengfei, a car salesperson, who said he came early with his family to secure a good spot to see the fireworks. I think I'm lucky to be standing here, said Yan Qianhua, a sales executive. A lot of people who want to come probably wouldn't be able to see the corner of the Bird's Nest (Olympic stadium). Security in Beijing has been stepped up before Friday's opening ceremony, with police blocking off streets surrounding the stadium and preventing the crowds from getting too close. I witnessed a streak of blue smoke, but that's good, that's ok, said Sun Runsheng, a Beijing resident. I don't ask for too much, he added.

item.description:
(3 Feb 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4364412
President Joe Biden is sending about 2,000 U.S.-based troops to Poland and Germany and shifting 1,000 soldiers from Germany to Romania as demonstrations of American commitments to allies on NATO's eastern flank amid fears of a Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Pentagon said Wednesday. Pentagon press secretary John Kirby said the soon-to-deploy U.S. forces are intended to temporarily bolster U.S. and allied defensive positions and will not enter Ukraine. We're just ready to go and support whatever the nation needs us to do, U.S. Army Lt. Col. Brad Jordan says. The newly announced U.S. troop deployments are in line with expectations based on Biden administration efforts to reassure allies and demonstrate U.S. resolve without undermining efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the Ukraine crisis. The U.S. already has several thousand troops in Poland, and Romania is host to a NATO missile defense system that Russia considers a threat to its security. Biden notably has not sent American military reinforcements to the three Baltic countries on NATO's eastern flank — Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania — that are former states of the Soviet Union. Of the 2,000 deploying from Fort Bragg, North Carolina, about 1,700 are members of the 82nd Airborne Division infantry brigade, who will go to Poland. The other 300 are with the 18th Airborne Corps and will deploy to Germany as what the Pentagon called a joint task force-capable headquarters.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) Germany expressed regret Friday that Russia has announced the suspension of mutual military inspections at a time of heightened tensions between Moscow and NATO. The inspections are intended as confidence-building measures among members of the Organizations for Security and Cooperation in Europe. A spokesman for Germany's Foreign Ministry said Russia recently announced it would suspend the inspections until the end of February, citing the spread of the omicron variant. Because of this an inspection on Russian territory in the border region of Ukraine, Belarus and Russia, which Latvia requested and Russia had previously agreed to, won't currently be possible, said the spokesman, Christofer Burger. We expressly regret this step because particularly in the current situation anything which creates greater transparency would help reduce tensions, he said. That's why we are calling on Russia to voluntarily and extensively inform OSCE member states about its activities. Burger said Russia had also unilaterally canceled inspections it was due to conduct in Germany.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) An important ecological reserve in Tierra del Fuego archipelago in southern Chile is under threat from forest fires which have already devastated more than 1,200 hectares close to the area. The blaze, which started on 25 January, threatens the Karukinka Natural Park, an area of precious ecosystems and biodiversity. The fire has reached Forestal Russfin forests bordering the park. Emilia Undurraga, Chile's agriculture minister, travelled to the region to monitor firefighting efforts on Thursday. National Forest Corporation team members are coordinating the fire control operation. Felipe Valencia, incident fire commander, said the blaze was spreading faster than usual because of a particular type of oak tree found in the area. He said it produced the heaviest combustion that can exist, causing the flames to spread horizontally and vertically at the same time. Karukinka Nature Park is an ancestral territory of the native Selk'nam people in Patagonia, one of the world's best-preserved southernmost forests.

item.description:
(3 Feb 2022) West African regional leaders refrained Thursday from imposing sanctions against the new military junta in Burkina Faso, instead requesting that the new rulers propose a firm date for returning the country to democratic rule. The regional bloc known as ECOWAS had called the meeting to discuss Burkina Faso, but the spate of military power grabs and coup attempts throughout the region weighed heavily at the gathering in Ghana's capital. Three of the 15 countries in the bloc are currently suspended because of military coups: Mali, Guinea and Burkina Faso. Earlier this week, security forces quelled a coup attempt in Guinea-Bissau too. The regional bloc has announced economic sanctions against junta leaders and their families in Guinea and Mali. It's added even more punishing economic penalties on Mali after elections were delayed by several more years. But it didn't announce any economic sanctions yet against the military rulers in Burkina Faso. Instead, ECOWAS reaffirmed its condemnation of the coup in Ouagadougou, and called for the immediate release of ousted President Roch Marc Christian Kabore. The bloc also announced it intends to send a stabilization force to Guinea-Bissau where gunmen tried to topple the president earlier this week. This is something that we will do very, very rapidly,” ECOWAS Commission President Jean-Claude Kassi Brou said.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) The U.K. Health Secretary on Friday joined other senior government ministers in defending remarks made by Prime Minister Boris Johnson where he claimed the leader of the opposition did not prosecute serial sex offender Jimmy Saville while he was Director of Public Prosecutions. Sajid Javid said on Friday that Labour party leader Sir Keir Starmer deserved respect for his role as head of prosecutions, and that Johnson had come out and clarified those remarks. Johnson was rocked Thursday by the resignation of his policy chief, Munira Mirza, a trusted adviser who worked with him for more than a decade. Mirza stood by the prime minister amid “partygate” revelations that Johnson and his staff broke the rules they had imposed on the country. But she said Johnson’s “scurrilous accusation” this week that an opposition leader had failed to stop a notorious pedophile was the final straw. Following her resignation, several other senior government officials have left their posts - chief of staff Dan Rosenfield, communications director Jack Doyle and principal private secretary Martin Reynolds. Elena Narozanski, who worked in Mirza’s policy unit, resigned Friday. Conservative lawmakers loyal to Johnson have claimed the departures were of a planned overhaul to restore order to his 10 Downing Street office. Javid on Friday saying the Prime Minister had his full support.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Final preparations were underway Friday for the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Beijing. The ceremony is set to start at 8pm local time (1400 GMT). It will take place at Beijing's National Stadium. Many Western countries are staging a diplomatic boycott of the event, citing China's record on human rights. Beijing is the first city to host both a Winter and a Summer Games, having staged the Summer Olympics in 2008.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4363515
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy on Friday sought to play down fears of a war between his country and Russia, saying in a news conference that he did not believe that the situation is worse now than it was in early 2021 when Russia began amassing troops on the border between the two nations. President Joe Biden on Thursday warned Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy that there is a distinct possibility that Russia could take military action against the former Soviet state in February. Russia has repeatedly denied having any such plans. Zelenskyy, however, sought to play down the war fears, said on Friday that Western alarm over an imminent invasion has prompted many investors in the country's financial markets to cash out. Meanwhile the head of a US Congressional delegation to Kyiv claimed on Friday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had united his adversaries amid the threat of conflict in Ukraine. He's united the EU, he's united the NATO members, he's united the Ukrainian people and he's united the United States Congress, said Gregory Meeks. The representatives, headed by Meeks, are on a visit to Kyiv to meet with senior Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. While there are no plans and no desires for American boots on the ground here, we must do all that we can short of that to help the Ukrainians, said Republican Mark Green.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) French President Emmanuel Macron held a video conference with Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan, Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev and European Council President Charles Michel on Friday. The leaders discussed the volatile situation at the border between two the ex-Soviet neighbours and regional tensions. Armenia and Azerbaijan have been locked in a decades-old dispute over the separatist region of Nagorno-Karabakh, a region that lies within Azerbaijan but was under the control of ethnic Armenian forces backed by Armenia since a separatist war there ended in 1994. Fierce fighting that erupted in September 2020 ended six weeks later with a Russia-brokered peace deal that saw Azerbaijan gain control of a significant part of Nagorno-Karabakh and reclaim all the regions that were controlled by Armenian forces outside the separatist region.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) Novak Djokovic on Friday was flanked with honors at a small Adriatic Sea resort in Montenegro, as fresh doubt emerged over the timing of the positive COVID-19 test he used to enter Australia in an attempt to compete in the Australian Open. The BBC reported on Friday that there are discrepancies in the numbers of his tests that were issued by the health authorities in Serbia with the numbers of other tests issued at the same time in the Balkan country. Djokovic's media team and the Institute of Public Health in Serbia did not immediately respond to a request for comment from the Associated Press. Senior Serbian health officials have previously said that his test was valid and issued by a relevant institution. Djokovic was deported from Australia and barred from playing in the Australian Open earlier this month after a 11-day visa saga on the eve of the tournament because he failed to meet Australia's strict COVID-19 vaccination requirements. To enter Australia, Djokovic submitted a positive COVID-19 test issued in Serbia from Dec. 16 for a visa exemption on the grounds that he had contracted the disease prior to the tournament. The 34-year-old player is not vaccinated and the Australian government decided to cancel his visa and deport Djokovic, saying his presence in Australia could stir anti-vaccination sentiments. Djokovic has said he would make no public comments until the end of the Australia Open. On Friday, several hundred people greeted Djokovic outside the municipal building in Budva as he arrived there to receive a plaque declaring him an honorary citizen of the town. Top Budva official Marko Carevic also presented Djokovic with an Orthodox Christian icon in gratitude for helping preserve the Serbian people and the Serbian church in Montenegro. Djokovic is adored in his native Serbia and among the Serbs in neighboring Montenegro, a small nation of some 620,000 people. Since he returned home, Djokovic was seen visiting churches and attending liturgies in both Serbia and Montenegro.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Members of a Ukrainian paramilitary unit have begun training civilian volunteers in the capital city in case of a Russian invasion. The Georgian Legion, formed in large part by ethnic Georgian volunteers to fight against Russian aggression in Ukraine in 2014, now includes people of various nationalities. Those who have joined include people from countries such as the U.S. and Albania, recruited to help bring more foreign volunteers to the group. Justin Dee from the U.S., who has previously served in the French Foreign Legion, says he is hoping to get more Americans involved to form the unit and be deployed to eastern Ukraine. Currently there are few U.S. citizens in the Georgian Legion, but according to its commander, by the end of February at least 30 more Americans could be joining. Emanuel Bazanji from Albania was a professional soldier for the Albanian military forces before joining the Georgian Legion three-and-a-half years ago. According to Bazanji, members of the legion are on rotation, some are deployed to the east and others are training civilians in Kyiv. The training of civilians takes place three days per week, for four hours. The Commander of the Georgian Legion, Mamuka Mamulashvili, said they usually trained army or militia troops, but that this time they decided to help with training civilians. According to Mamulashvili, up to 3,000 volunteers will be trained at the Georgian Legion base in Kyiv.

item.description:
(29 Jan 2022) Hundreds of Kosovars on Saturday held a protest against the government's plans to increase the price of energy. Protesters gathered in the capital Pristina and moved toward the parliament building, shouting anti-government slogans against the Prime Minister Albin Kurti. Police scuffled with protesters as they tried to guard the entrance of the government building and demonstrators threw light bulbs that smashed against windows. Dardan Molliqaj, organizer of the protest, told the crowd that, if the government do not change tack, we will be here every day, stronger, bigger and more courageous. The government says it is unable to keep supplies at the current price. Electricity in Kosovo costs 6 cents per kWh, the cheapest in Europe as household tariffs are heavily subsidized. Kosovo produces all its energy with coal-fired and ailing power plants and has been obliged to import up to 40% of its energy. Prices are now up to ten times higher compared to a year ago.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4363406
Despite relative calm in Ukraine's east, soldiers who have been defending against Russian encroachment are preparing for an escalation. At the Novooleksandrivka outpost, the soldiers in the small garrison are wary as they keep watch over the landscape. Soldiers worry that a first strike could be in easter Ukraine, where pro-Russia separatists have been in control since 2014. Soldier Vikor Beliekov wonders if an attack might come from the sea to the south. Our navy is not enough to withstand heavy attack, he told the Associated Press, I think the coastline could be easily captured. Everyone thinks through Kharkiv or Donbass but it's a wrong point of view. If they decide to attack, they will do it from the sea. Tensions have soared in recent weeks as Russia moved about 100,000 troops near the border with Ukraine. NATO allies are bolstering their presence in the Baltics, and the U.S. has put 8,500 troops on alert.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) A third day of efforts to rescue a 5-year-old boy who fell into a well in northern Morocco were halted shortly on Friday following concerns about ground stability, fueling despair among those hoping to reach him. The boy, identified as Rayan, has been trapped inside the well since Tuesday evening. He fell into the 32-meter (105-feet) deep well located outside his home in the northern village of Ighran in Morocco's Chefchaouen province. Digging has stopped momentarily out of concern that the ground surrounding the well could collapse, rescue committee member Abdelhadi Temrani told local television 2M. Search crews used five bulldozers to dig vertically to a depth of more than 31 meters, according to Morocco's official MAP news agency. Preparations are underway to start digging horizontally to create a pathway to reach the trapped boy, MAP said, adding that experts in topographical engineering were called upon for help. Rescue workers used a rope to provide oxygen and water to the boy, but were unable to reach the hole where he is trapped due its narrow diameter. Medical staff, including specialists in resuscitation, are on site to attend to the boy once he is pulled out, with a helicopter on standby to transport him to the nearest hospital. The Moroccan government said Thursday that all efforts are being made to help save the boy. Moroccans took to social media to offer their hopes for the boy's survival, using the hashtag #SaveRayan which has brought global attention to the rescue efforts. I pray and beg God that he comes out of that well alive and safe, his mother Wassima Kharchich said.

item.description:
(29 Jan 2022) LEAD IN: Asia is at the gateway of a new lunar year and anticipation is high for the Year of the Tiger which begins on February 1st. In the East the tiger isn't just a ferocious animal, it is seen as a powerful symbol of protection from bad things and those born in the Year of the Tiger are credited with being ambitious, courageous and generous.
STORY-LINE: Here in Leofoo Village Theme Park in northern Taiwan, the tigers play. Although the animals are revered here, there are no tigers living in the wild in this country. This theme park has 12, some of them are white tigers and the rest are Bengal tigers. According to the Chinese zodiac this year 2022 belongs to the tiger. Tigers in this zoo are kept in different enclosures, according to each animal's personality and physical conditions. Zookeeper Randy Liu says the cats here are very mischievous. When we clean their place, they take our brooms as cat teasers. When we are cleaning up, they play with our brooms. They (tigers) also urinate on us when they are behind us when we clean up. In winter, we would feel something warm on our back. Then, we know that we've been urinated on. The smell is quite strong, but we are used to it, and we say to ourselves 'here you go again…' Normal people would hardly accept such a thing, says Liu. Since 2017, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has recognised two tiger subspecies. These are commonly referred to as the continental tiger and the Sunda island tigers which can now only be found in Sumatra. According to the IUCN the continental tigers include Bengal, Malayan, Indochinese and the Amur, which is commonly called the Siberian tiger. Liu believes the role of the zoo is to ensure the survival of the species that still survive. He explains: One single tiger needs a very wide space to live. The biggest problems tigers encounter are the loss of habitat and species. The role of a zoo is to keep the species existing. We try to give tigers the best living quality under limited conditions. So, in terms of multiplication, we are not seeking unlimited breeding. We would choose the most rare gene specification, and our best conditions to keep tigers. Here in Taiwan the tiger is deified and worshipped, it even has its own temple. The Tiger Temple is located on a steep slope on a remote area in northern Taipei. But worshipers are still numerous. Real estate manager Randy Lin comes here regularly and he attributes his good fortune to the Tiger God. Next year is the Year of the Tiger. So, today, I am here at the Tiger Temple to pray to the Tiger God for a safe and peaceful year as well as a prosperous career before the New Year comes. I have been visiting this temple for a year now. The Tiger God has been good to me. My career path was also smooth, says Lin. Chen Forng-shean, a Taiwanese artist sculptor who also doubles as a ceramist and calligrapher recently sculpted a miniature tiger in gold. At only 2 millimetres by 3 millimetres it has to be seen through a magnifying glass and Chen claims it's the tiniest tiger a human has ever sculpted. Chen says: Its (the sculpted gold tiger) head has eyes, nose and mouth. It has its mouth opened. The most difficult part is that its front right paw is raised. This is a 3-millimetre tiger. I had to make its limbs, head and tail. It was very difficult to make. You can appreciate this tiger from all directions. Chen believes the Year of the Tiger will be an auspicious year. The Year of the Tiger starts on February 1, which marks the first day of the year on the lunar calendar.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4363392
With its opening ceremony now just a week away, China has been using the Beijing Winter Olympics to promote winter sports, many of which are new to most Chinese, for fitness and business opportunities. The push has proved lifechanging for Li Wei. The tall, tanned 36-year-old farmer-turned ski coach works December to March at a resort in the Yanqing district, which will host skiing, luge and other sliding events for the Beijing Games. Skiing boosted my income to another level, said Li, who charges 400 to 500 yuan ($60 to $80) per lesson — almost as much as his family earns in a week growing corn during warmer months. Many in Beijing have long enjoyed winter ice skating on canals and lakes. But now, young Chinese are expanding their aspirations from basketball, football and gymnastics to sports such as hockey and skiing. The government and private companies have built ice rinks and ski runs. Public schools are adding skating and other winter sports. Parents are opening their wallets to pay for hockey teams and skating lessons. Villages near ski slopes are building inns to serve well-heeled tourists. Wu Mengkai, 11, said hockey has turned him to being more extroverted and a very sunny person. You can't be introverted when you play ice hockey, Wu said. You have to be brave enough to fight. The Chinese capital has tightened anti-virus measures and ordered mass testing of some 2 million people in one district following outbreaks. Some families are barred from leaving their homes. The Winter Games will take place without foreign tourists or ordinary spectators under China's zero tolerance strategy that aims to keep the virus out of the country. Athletes, reporters and officials are required to stay within areas that isolate them from general public. Foreign sports brands see growth opportunities in China but are frustrated that marketing and business development are hampered by the anti-virus controls and ban on most foreigners from entering China. That's kind of put a damper on things, said Jeffrey Potter, president of Proskatecorner Pte. Ltd., the China distributor of American hockey equipment maker True. If not for the virus, the marketing boost from the Olympics would have been bigger, really helping the economy and making hockey more popular, Potter said. Despite the Games being off limits to ordinary spectators because of the pandemic, enthusiasm for winter sports remain high. I want to be an ice hockey player in the future, said eight-year-old Guo Yuchen, who took up the sport at four and trains seven hours a week at a rink in Beijing. Then I can bring glory to my country.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Thailand's largest Chinese community held its annual Lunar New Year parade on Thursday, a celebration awash with dragons, acrobats and red and gold apparel. Marching bands and pop-up shrines contributed to the festive atmosphere at the parade, which took place in the central Thai city of Nakhon Sawan, some 250 kilometers (160 miles) north of Bangkok. The event was part of week-long festivities being observed under tight COVID-19 restrictions.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) An oil slick off the coast of Thailand continued to expand Friday and was approaching beaches on the east coast, home to fragile coral and sea grass, officials said. The oil leak from an undersea hose at an offshore mooring point used to load tankers was stopped early Wednesday morning, but not before 140 to 375 barrels, or between about 22,000 and 60,000 liters (5,800 to 15,850 gallons), spilled into the Gulf of Thailand, according to Star Petroleum Refining, the operating company. There are now two slicks, a small one about one square kilometer (less than half a square mile) that is closer to the coast and another that has broadened to 47 square kilometers (18 square miles) that is not far behind it, said Siam Lawawirojwong, director of the department that deals with disasters at Thailand's Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency. The Royal Thai Navy, which has been part of the cleanup and containment effort, said the main slick is expected to reach an area of coast including the Khao Lam Ya National Park by about 10 p.m. The park is home to a variety of seabirds and fish. In preparation, floating booms were being deployed to try and trap the oil and contain it so that it can be collected from the surface and removed. Pornsri Sutthanarak, deputy director-general of the Marine and Coastal Resources Department, said Thursday that if the oil reaches the coast, it might also affect 59 acres of coral and 118 acres of sea grass, causing environmental damage that would take time to rehabilitate. Initial estimates from Thailand's Pollution Control Department were that much more oil had leaked than reported by Star Petroleum Refining, and Siam said it was not possible at this juncture to say exactly how much was in the slicks. Speaking on the beach in preparation for clean up efforts Governor of Rayong Charnna Iamsaeng said the company that is responsible for this mistake must take full responsibility. The leak occurred at about 9 p.m. local time Tuesday at a mooring station about 20 kilometers (12 miles) southeast of the Map Ta Phut Industrial Estate, south of Bangkok, Star Petroleum Refining said. On Thursday the main slick covered 11.65 square kilometers (4.5 square miles) and Star Petroleum Refining said it had been spraying dispersants on the slick to try and clear it from the surface as it approaches Rayong province beaches. In all, four ships have been deployed to skim oil off of the sea's surface and another seven have been spraying the dispersants, the company said.

item.description: (4 Feb 2022) Inside of a few remaining houses in Slavyanoserbsk outside the rebel-controlled Luhansk, people live right with the frontline less than a kilometre (0.6 miles) away. Ninety-two-year-old Lida remembers World War II, so houses ruined by artillery shelling is nothing new to her. She blames everything on the former Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko. An LPR (Luhansk People's Republic) militia fighter, who gave The Associated Press only his call sign (The Bear), talked about the cultural abyss between the two sides. We have our own ideals here
item.title: People still living on the frontline in Ukraine

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) FOR CLEAN VERSION SEE STORY NUMBER: 4364550
The opening ceremony for the Beijing Winter Olympics ended with a barrage of fireworks, marking the start of the Games under heavy virus restrictions.
The ceremony ended with the lighting of the torch on a large spinning snowflake, after which torchbearers brought the flame to a cauldron outside the National Stadium. With the dimming of the lights, Beijing became the first city to host both Winter and Summer Games. The Olympics - and the opening ceremony - are always an exercise in performance for the host nation, a chance to showcase its culture, define its place in the world and flaunt its best side.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Iraq's Yazidi community, from which many women and children were kidnapped and enslaved by the Islamic State group in 2014, welcomed on Friday the news of the death of the IS leader during a U.S. raid in Syria. Displaced Yazidis living in Sharia Camp, in Iraq's Dohuk governorate — many of whom are women who suffered at the hands of IS — expressed relief about the death of Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi. The IS leader blew himself up along with members of his family as American forces raided his Syria hideout Thursday, the U.S. said. Gawri Khedhir, a Yazidi woman from Sinjar, was taken along with her family by IS militants when they took over the district in August 2014. She was taken by the militants to the nearby Tel Afar town before managing to escape in 2016. Her husband, son and daughter are still missing since then. According to an Associated Press report published in May 2020, al-Qurayshi was a religious judge at the time and labeled one of the architects of the militant group's enslavement of Iraq's Yazidi religious minority. He rose to become deputy to IS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi. The operation of killing al-Qurayshi came as IS has been trying for a resurgence, with a series of attacks in the region, including an assault late last month to seize a prison in northeast Syria holding at least 3,000 IS detainees, it's boldest operation in years. Hana Shakir, a Yazidi survivor who was in IS captivity and returned in 2018, said she still has fears that the militants might make a comeback. We want to achieve our rights. I mean the elimination of those who did this to us, she said, speaking from her tent in Sharia Camp. IS tried to exterminate the Yazidis, a religious minority with beliefs that distinguish them from Muslim and Christian worshippers in the region. IS destroyed villages and religious sites, lined men up and shot them before kidnapping thousands of women and children, trading them in modern-day chattel slavery. The United Nations has called the IS assault on the Yazidis' ancestral homeland in northern Iraq in 2014 a genocide, saying the Yazidis' 400,000-strong community had all been displaced, captured or killed.

item.description:
(4 Feb 2022) Hundreds of migrants gathered outside the Mexican immigration office in Tapachula, a border city with Guatemala, to protest against police raids on small hotels and other places of shelter where migrants have been staying. The city has become a way station for migrants from Central America, Haiti, Cuba and other places, because Mexico requires many people file for refugee or asylum status there. Raids have occurred before, but this week activists say agents swept up people from sidewalks outside migrant shelters. Many are forcibly returned to their home countries. Agents are prohibited from entering the shelters to detain people, but many migrants have camped out around the overcrowded facilities. Salvadoran migrant Mario Guzmán was detained by immigration agents a few weeks ago in Tapachula's central park, even though he had papers showing he made a claim for asylum. They told us those papers were no good, they were fake, and they ripped them up, said Guzmán, who was held for three weeks at an immigration detention center and given two weeks to leave Mexico. A group of about 30 migrants called for a hunger strike to demand that authorities speed up the issue of papers so that they can leave Tapachula. Irineu Mujica, an activist with People without Borders, said it is taking almost five months for migrants to get their papers, so he joined the hunger strikers promising to be with the migrants for as long as my body can handle. The immigration institute said Monday there has been a surge in detentions, with the number of migrants detained in Mexico up 78% in January from a year ago. It said 16,740 migrants, mainly from Central America, were detained in January, compared to 9,406 over the same month last year. It was unclear if the number of migrants was less last year because of last winter's coronavirus surge, or for some other reason. Children and young people under age 18 made up 14.5% of the migrants detained, and a total of 780 were found to be unaccompanied by family members, the agency said.

item.description:
(28 Jan 2022) The city of New York has given an emotional final salute to a rookie police officer gunned down with his partner a week ago. A funeral Mass for Jason Rivera was held Friday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mayor Eric Adams, who is a retired police captain, says he sees an echo of himself in the slain officer who had joined a department he had seen as flawed in hopes of improving it. The 22-year-old Rivera was recently married and barely into his second year on the force. He and Officer Wilbert Mora were fatally wounded when a gunman ambushed them in an apartment as they responded to a family dispute. During the funeral service, New York City Police Commissioner Keechant Sewell posthumously promoted Rivera to the rank of Detective First Grade.
